choices.text:
Before Cam broke his right arm, he was able to type 9 words per minute on his phone.  After he broke his arm, he had to use his left hand for a while, and he could only type 6 words per minute. What is the difference between the number of words he could type in 5 minutes before and after he broke his arm
To find the difference between the number of words Cam could type in 5 minutes before and after breaking his right arm, we need to calculate the time it took him to type a certain amount of words with both hands.

Before breaking his arm:
Cam could type 9 words per minute on his phone (wpm). In one minute, he can type 1/6th of that speed, which is 0.15 wpm (1/6 \* 9 = 1.5 / 6 = 0.157143 wpm). So in 5 minutes, Cam could type:

5 \* 0.157143 wpm = 0.7857 wpm (rounded to two decimal places)

After breaking his arm and using his left hand only for a while, he can now type at a speed of 6 words per minute with his left hand (wpm). In one minute, Cam can type 1/6th of that speed as well. So in 5 minutes:

5 \* 1/6 wpm = 0.8333 wpm (rounded to two decimal places)

Now we need to find the difference between the words typed with both hands before and after breaking his arm:

Difference = Typed with both hands after injury - Typed with both hands initially
Difference = 0.7857 wpm - 0.8333 wpm
Difference = -0.4476 wpm (rounded to two decimal places)

So, Cam's typing speed decreased by approximately 0.45 words per minute after breaking his right arm and using only his left hand for a while.
